fields.Title: Evaluating the use of seed introductions to initiate viable slickspot peppergrass populations at the Orchard Combat Training Center: 2016-2019
fields.Publisher: Report on file at Idaho Army National Guard
fields.Description/Abstract:
SUMMARY OF FINDINGS
•	Of the roughly 550,000 seeds released across 110 slick spots at three sites in the OCTC in 2016, a total of 675 seedlings (42 annuals, 633 vegetative rosettes) were found in 2017.  The numbers of seedlings found in 2018 and 2019 were much lower (N = 37 and 33, respectively).
•	Harvester ants (present at 8 of the 110 slick spots) removed most L. papilliferum seeds within a few days of their introduction.
•	In each of the three years after seed introduction (2017-2019), most seedlings were located within 20 cm of the central stake in each slick spot.  Maximum dispersal distance of seeds that germinated was 2 m.
•	Seedlings that flowered as annuals in 2017 (N=42) produced seed-bearing fruits similar in number and size to those of nearby natural populations of L. papilliferum.  None of the eight annuals found in 2018 survived long enough to produce seed-bearing fruit.  In 2019, two annuals flowered, only one of which produced seed-bearing fruits.
•	Of the 633 vegetative rosettes produced in 2017, 60 survived the winter and flowered in 2018.  However, most of these biennials, despite being pollinated, experienced complete reproductive failure as a result of herbivory by small mammals.  None of the 29 vegetative rosettes produced in 2018 survived to flower in 2019.
•	Many of the insect species that visited L. papilliferum flowers at the three study locations are known to be effective pollinators of this plant.
